title: Kate Middleton and Prince William ride in tuk-tuk for reception in Pakistan
text:

Prince William and Kate Middleton were driven in this specially painted tuk-tuk as they arrived at a reception in Pakistan's National Monument.

Construction of the impressive heritage site and museum began in 2004 and is meant to symbolise the unity of Pakistanis.

It is located on the western Shakarparian Hills in the country's capital, Islamabad.

A video released by the British High Commission shows the tuk-tuk being specially painted with the Union Jack and the Pakistani national flag.

The couple arrived in the Commonwealth country on Monday evening for an official five-day visit in the hope of forging closer ties.

(Image: Getty Images)

(Image: PA)

Following a visit to a school in the capital, Islamabad, on Tuesday - their first full day of engagements - William and Kate travelled to the Margalla Hills National Park.

The royal couple arrived at a visitor centre nestled at the foot of the hills to hear about conservation work taking place.

Following on the theme of education in the country, they also met schoolchildren learning about environmental protection.

(Image: British High Commission)

(Image: The Daily Mirror)

The Duke spoke poignantly about Diana after being told girls at the Islamabad school were "big fans" - to which he replied "I was a big fan of my mother too".

Earlier today, Kate and William were pictured interacting jokingly with the children at the government-run school in Islamabad.

The couple knelt down to chat with the children who seemed excited to be meeting the royal visitors.

(Image: Samir Hussein/WireImage)

After meeting with some of the schoolgirls during the visit to the Islamabad school, William was told the girls were “big fans of your mother”

Reporters said he gave a “broad, slightly wistful, smile” before replying: “You were, really? Oh that’s very sweet of you. I was a big fan of my mother too.

"She came here three times. I was very small.”
description: The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, otherwise known as Prince William and Kate Middleton, rode in the tuk-tuk as part of their five-day visit to the Commonwealth country
